title: Threshold Regression Models in Dynamic Heterogeneous Panels
abstractText:
The research project proposes the rigorous investigation of nonlinear mechanisms within a dynamic heterogeneous panel setting when the number of time periods is small relative to the number of cross-section units. The relative absence of studies in this area is surprising, considering the well-established literatures on GMM and bias-corrected estimation of linear dynamic panels, and time series regime-switching models. So this project aims to fill this gap by addressing the joint issue as how best to model asymmetric mechanisms and cross-sectional heterogeneity.

This project focuses on threshold regression models in dynamic panels, and advances two alternative methodologies: an extended GMM estimation and an iterative bootstrap-based bias corrected estimation procedure. The proposed framework can be extended in several dimensions including a threshold error correction model in dynamic panels, which is characterised by the common long-run relationship and the regime-dependent short-run dynamics.

The project will develop the associated asymptotic theory and the sub-sampling-based inference for deriving (non-standard) sampling distribution theory. The small sample performance will be evaluated via stochastic simulations. We then apply the proposed techniques to a variety of applications in Economics and Finance, eg testing the validity of alternative theories of the capital structure and redressing the growth convergence literature.
